SENT.plain: The anti-phospholipid syndrome (APS) is characterized by recurrent thrombosis and occurrence of anti-phospholipid antibodies (aPL)
aPL are necessary, but not sufficient for the clinical manifestations of APS
Growing evidence suggests a role of innate immune cells, in particular polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMN) and Toll-like receptors (TLR) to be additionally involved
aPL activate endothelial cells and monocytes through a TLR4-dependent signalling pathway
Whether this is also relevant for PMN in a similar way is currently not known

To address this issue, we used purified PMN from healthy donors and stimulated them in the presence or absence of human monoclonal aPL and the TLR4 agonist LPS monitoring neutrophil effector functions, namely the oxidative burst, phagocytosis, L-Selectin shedding and IL-8 production
aPL alone were only able to induce minor activation of PMN effector functions at high concentrations
However, in the additional presence of LPS the activation threshold was markedly lower indicating a synergistic activation pathway of aPL and TLR in PMN
In summary, our results indicate that PMN effector functions are directly activated by aPL and boosted by the additional presence of microbial products
This highlights a role for PMN as important innate immune effector cells that contribute to the pathophysiology of APS
